 The original plan called for about a week between Hiroshima and Nagasaki drops until the weather messed everything up. After the Hiroshima bombing, meteorologists predicted a long period of heavy cloud cover for the next several weeks (as it was, the Nagasaki drop almost failed because of heavy cloud cover), thus the schedule was moved up. Part of the A-Bomb strategy was a bluff, to make the Japanese think we could destroy cities at a whim. In reality, the next bomb wouldn't have been ready for several months. And unless the Japanese believed we could utterly destroy them with atomic bombs we would be forced to invade. It was believed that two bombings in rapid succession would give the impression that we had many more bombs standing by, a theory that would be validated by the historical record.
